You precisely follow the given Task and use the Data when provided. When Data is not provided, create some examples.

# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Data

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)

Here is a solution for your problem in Julia.

```julia
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = string.(map((d)->split(string(d), "-")[1]*split(string(d), "-")[2], df[:dt])) |> x -> map(x) do ym
        join([split(ym, '-')[1], split(ym, '-')[2]]) do a, b
            string(parse(Int64, a)*100 + parse(Int64, b))
        end
    end
end
```
This function `add_yearmonth` adds the column `ym` to your DataFrame `df`. The value of this new column is an integer representing the year and month from the DateTime column `dt`, concatenated in the format "yyyymm". The parsing into integers and joining them as a string again is done because we cannot have two different types (Int64 and String) in DataFrames.

Now if you call your function with given data, it would look like:
```julia
df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)
```
Note that the result will be DataFrame with added column `ym`.
